speaker: Niles
text: Oh, did I mention?  Two of my "Fear of Commitment" group have announced they're getting married.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, congratulations.

speaker: Niles
text: Thank you.  There's a downside though - they're New Age types - the wedding's to be held in the woods.

speaker: Frasier
text: So?

speaker: Niles
text: I need a date.  You know how the women in my crowd tend to droop outdoors.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well Niles, there are all sorts of different women in the world.  Perhaps if you tiptoed beyond the fringes of your precious circle, cast a wider net..

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier?  That woman by the side of the road, spearing trash!

speaker: Frasier
text: Not that wide.

speaker: Niles
text: No, no.  It's Roz!

speaker: Frasier
text: My God, it is! _(he stops beside her)_

speaker: Niles
text: If she realizes we've recognised her, she'll be utterly humiliated.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh my God!  You're not seeing me!  Go away!

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz!  What on earth are you doing here?

speaker: Roz
text: Just let me in.

speaker: Niles
text: Wait, I'll spread papers _(does so, all over the back seat)_

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, yes.  Thank you, Niles. _(to Roz)_ All right.

speaker: Roz
text: Okay, let's go.

speaker: Frasier
text: What?  What do you mean, "Let's go"?  I can't do that, I don't even know why you're here.

speaker: Roz
text: About a month ago, I got stopped doing sixty in a thirty-mile- an-hour zone.  It was either a huge fine or community service. So here I am.  It's a nightmare.  Breathing exhaust fumes, using a spatula to scrape up roadkills...

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, at least look on the bright side.  You're outdoors, you can enjoy nature, you're beautifying our highways...

speaker: Roz
text: Frasier, I found an ear!

speaker: Frasier
text: Are there no other services you could have performed?

speaker: Roz
text: The only other option was visiting old people in a retirement home.

speaker: Frasier
text: And you chose this?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, think about it.  Walking the streets, picking up trash; You can see how Roz would go with the familiar. _(this earns him a clip round the head from Roz)_

speaker: Roz
text: Old people just make me uncomfortable.

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, have you considered that your discomfort around the elderly may stem from your own fear of growing old?

speaker: Roz
text: _(sarcastically)_ Wow!  D'you think? _(sees something)_ Oh my god!

speaker: Frasier
text: What?

speaker: Roz
text: It's my supervisor.  Hit the gas.

speaker: Frasier
text: I can't.  It might be illegal.

speaker: Roz
text: _(putting trash spear to Niles's head)_ Move, or your brother gets it!

speaker: Frasier
text: Absolutely not!

speaker: Roz
text: _(shifts aim)_ All right, the headrest.

speaker: Frasier
text: Off we go.   _Scene Two - Frasier's Apartment. Frasier and Niles enter as Daphne helps Martin with his exercises._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, well dad.  Doing your exercises.  Very good.

speaker: Daphne
text: _(to Martin, as he raises his knee)_ There you go! Congratulations, Mr Crane!  You finally got your knee past your ribcage.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, it's no big deal.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, it's more than Lilith could accomplish after five years of marriage.

speaker: Daphne
text: You know, it's so gratifying seeing your father make these little improvements.  It's days like this I'm glad that I took this position.

speaker: Niles
text: _(watching Daphne from behind, as she is bent over)_ We're all glad you took this position.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, you know Daphne, I must say there are some times I envy you.  Here you go, Niles.  _He throws a bottle of water to Niles, which sails past his head when he doesn't react.  Frasier hands him the other bottle._

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, I'm just saying it's always gratifying to see some reward for your efforts.  Lately, that's something I've been lacking in my own work.

speaker: Niles
text: How so?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, well you know, back in private practice I could spend months, even years with a patient, see the fruits of my labour.  Now, somebody calls in, I give my advice, and never know how things work out.  I simply release my humble words into the airwaves and then they're gone forever, vanished.

speaker: Niles
text: So like my Tiffany cufflinks. _(at Frasier's stare)_ I'd hoped to wear them to my new age wedding, they've disappeared.

speaker: Frasier
text: So you know my pain!  Well, I'm not really dissatisfied, it's just that... well, Daphne, you know, you get to see your progress with dad; Niles, you have the upcoming marriage of your commitment phobics...

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, c'mon, you help people all the time.  You helped me just the other day.

speaker: Frasier
text: How?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I was worried because Eddie had lost his appetite, and remember what you said?

speaker: Frasier
text: If I remember rightly, I said, "Well, why don't you give him some of my truffle foie gras?"

speaker: Martin
text: Right.

speaker: Frasier
text: I was being funny.

speaker: Martin
text: ...Oh. _(covering)_ Well, yeah.  Well, I knew that.  Ha-ha. That just cheered me right up.  C'mon, Eddie!   _Scene Three - KACL. Frasier is waiting for Roz.  He checks the corridor.  Bulldog is getting chocolate from the vending machine._

speaker: Frasier
text: Excuse me, Bulldog?

speaker: Bulldog
text: What's up, doc? _(breaks into giggles)_

speaker: Frasier
text: Listen, have you seen Roz?  She's late.  My show goes on in thirty seconds.

speaker: Bulldog
text: You know what?  I'd dump her.

speaker: Frasier
text: That's a little extreme, don't you think?

speaker: Bulldog
text: No.  I fire everybody once a year.  Housekeepers, personal trainers, phutt.  You know, cut them off before they start copping an attitude.  Oh, oh - doctors are the worst of all. You pick up the same disease three or four times, they start lecturing you like it's your fault. _(re: chocolate)_ Want a bite?

speaker: Frasier
text: Not if you skipped it to me over a pool of disinfectant.  _He decides Roz isn't coming and goes back into his booth. He sits down and hits "On Air."_

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, Seattle.  Good afternoon, this is Dr Frasier Crane. You know, today we're going to do things just a little bit different.  For the past four years now I've been taking your calls and giving advice, and I was thinking, perhaps our listeners are wondering how things have turned out.  I know I do.  So today I invite those of you who've called in in the past to give us a holler, and we can catch up on how things have worked out for you.  All our lines are open...

speaker: Frasier
text: Come on.  Come on, you know the number. _(board lights up)_ Ah, there we are. _(opens line)_ Hello, this is Dr Frasier Crane.  How did I help you?

speaker: Chet
text: _(v.o.)_ Hello, Dr Crane, this is Chet from Whitby Island.  I gave you a call last year?  I was having problems with low self-esteem.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, ah, I see.  And did my advice help you to become more assertive?

speaker: Chet
text: Damn straight.  And now people say I'm downright arrogant. Well, you know what I say?  Screw 'em!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, perhaps you took my advice just a bit too far.

speaker: Chet
text: Who the hell are you?  Screw you too! _(line goes dead)_

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, as I give myself a well-deserved pat on the back, and Chet marches off to invade Poland, _(Roz finally walks in)_ let's just go to commercial. _(off air)_ Well Roz, glad you could join us.

speaker: Roz
text: You're lucky I made it at all.  I took your advice, went down to that retirement home to finish off my community service..

speaker: Frasier
text: Ooh, lot better than spearing trash, isn't it?

speaker: Roz
text: You tell me.  I started playing checkers with this old man, Mr. Krantz?  Well, things got a little competitive and he made a really bad move and I said, "You're a dead man!"

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, dear.  I think I see where this story is headed.

speaker: Roz
text: A minute later, he's lying sprawled across the board, pieces are everywhere, the whole place is screaming... when I pulled him up he still had a checker stuck to his forehead.

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, I am so sorry.  I, I can see how you could be very traumatised by this... _(on air)_ Hi, we're back.  That was a very catchy commercial, wasn't it?  Let's get back to it. Now given the circumstances, his age and his surroundings, surely this thing was sort of expected.

speaker: Roz
text: Not with this guy.  The whole reason I liked him was he was so youthful and robust. _(Bulldog enters)_ You should have seen him, Frasier.  He was raring to go, he kept bragging about how good he was and how much fun it was going to be, and he dies on me!

speaker: Bulldog
text: Hey, it happens to all guys, okay?

speaker: Frasier
text: Bulldog...

speaker: Bulldog
text: No, no.  This is a pet peeve of mine, doc.  Why is it always the guy's fault?  You know, if you chicks needed a little less booze to get from "maybe" to "yes," we'd be a lot more alert when the moment of truth arrives.

speaker: Frasier
text: Bulldog, Roz was playing checkers with an elderly gentleman and he died.

speaker: Bulldog
text: Oh, well.... when I said "We" I didn't mean me, because I don't have that... hey, you're a doctor, that was confidential! _(leaves)_

speaker: Roz
text: Well, guess it's back to scraping up roadkills.

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, Roz, surely you realise what happened today at the retirement home was an aberration.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, maybe so, but I wasn't comfortable being around old people to begin with and this certainly hasn't helped matters.

speaker: Frasier
text: Now Roz, listen.  If you're ever going to conquer your fear of aging you've got to get back down there and spend some time with these people.  You'll learn that they're really vital human beings.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, I'm still not convinced.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right then, think of it this way: there's been a lot of fog on the interstate lately and the caribou are migrating.  _Scene Four - Retirement home Roz is reading a story._

speaker: Roz
text: "As the train whistle screamed, and we started out of the station, I lowered the window and said: 'I'll be back.'  But somehow I knew I would never see her or Paris again.  The end." That was a pretty good book, wasn't it Mr Gouldenstein? Can I make you a nice hot cup of... _(realises)_ OH MY GOD!!   **ROZ'S KRANTZ AND GOULDENSTEIN ARE DEAD**  _Scene Five - Frasier's apartment. Eddie is doing tricks to amuse Martin and Daphne._

speaker: Martin
text: Come on boy, you can do it.  _Eddie stands on his hind legs and twirls.  The doorbell bing-bongs. Daphne goes to answer it as Frasier enters from his bedroom._

speaker: Martin
text: Hey-hey, Fras.  Look at that, he's dancin'.  He's practically doing a polka.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, good.  That should up his price when I sell him to the carnival.

speaker: Daphne
text: _(opening the door to Niles)_ Hello.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello, Daphne.

speaker: Martin
text: Back from the big wedding in the woods, huh?

speaker: Daphne
text: Yes, and don't you look nice.  Except, what's this sticky stuff all over your shoulder here?

speaker: Frasier
text: Did you finally find a date?

speaker: Niles
text: I asked Maris.

speaker: Daphne
text: _(examining goo)_ Sap.

speaker: Frasier
text: I think Daphne speaks for us all.  Just how the hell did this happen?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I was desperate for a date, and I, I knew Maris would be lonely this time of year.  It's cruise season, she never partakes.  She has an absolute terror of buffets.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, yes.  Legendary smorgaphobia.

speaker: Martin
text: So how did it go?  Or should I say, how big a scene did she make?

speaker: Niles
text: Actually she did quite well.  She willingly joined in the ceremonial chanting.  When the shaman invited those so inclined to embrace their favourite tree, Maris said the only tree she was willing to embrace was her family tree. Everyone laughed.  Well, I laughed.  Then it happened. They called for a group hug.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, dear.

speaker: Niles
text: Last time I saw her, she was racing towards her Mercedes, emitting a high-pitched shriek that caused the wedding doves to attack one another. _(the doorbell bing-bongs)_ Let me see if I can't find something to remove this sap._(goes to bedroom)_

speaker: Roz
text: Another one died.

speaker: Frasier
text: What?  What happened?

speaker: Martin
text: What's she talkin' about?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh.  Dad, Roz has been doing some community service down at a retirement home.  Apparently, for the second time this week one of her charges has died.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh.

speaker: Roz
text: They're calling me "The Angel Of Death" now.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well as you know, this isn't your fault.

speaker: Roz
text: Maybe it is.  I've never been good with plants or animals. Everything's always died on me.

speaker: Frasier
text: You have a cat. _(at Roz's look he realises)_ Oh.  I'm so sorry.

speaker: Daphne
text: Roz, death is an occupational hazard of working with older people.  Trust me.  I've lost more patients than I'd like to count.

speaker: Martin
text: You've never said anything about that to me.

speaker: Daphne
text: Didn't I? _(to Roz)_ Anyway, you just sit there, and I'll go make you a nice cup of tea. _(heads towards kitchen, followed by Martin)_

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, wait.  How many patients did you lose?

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, I don't know.  I used to keep a tally in my diary, but it made me a bit sad.

speaker: Martin
text: Was it more than five? _(they go into kitchen)_

speaker: Frasier
text: Now listen, Roz.  There's no way that you can feel guilty about this.  I mean, those men were going to die anyway.  If anything, you gave them some much-welcomed companionship in their final moments.

speaker: Roz
text: It just seems so unfair. _(Niles returns at this point)_ One minute he's lying in the bed, smiling and happy - ten seconds later, it's over.

speaker: Niles
text: For heaven's sake, it happens to every man a couple of times in his life.  Why can't you women take it as a compliment?  _End Of Act One.  Act Two._ **NOSES OFF** _Scene One - The Retirement Home Frasier and Roz are walking down the hallway.  Frasier has a firm grip on Roz._

speaker: Roz
text: Look, I appreciate you coming down here with me, but I don't think I can make it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, we have discussed this.  This is going to be your breakthrough day.

speaker: Roz
text: They hate me here!

speaker: Frasier
text: You're just overreacting.  There is no way they think you're the Angel of Death.

speaker: Roz
text: I'm leaving.

speaker: Frasier
text: No.  Roz, this is not like you.  The Roz I know is not a quitter, she's a fighter.

speaker: Roz
text: I just can't help thinking it's going to happen again.  They always die in threes.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh come, that's just celebrities.  C'mon.

speaker: Roz
text: Hi.  I'm Roz.

speaker: Moira
text: I'm Moira.  Come in.

speaker: Roz
text: How you feeling today?

speaker: Moira
text: Fine.

speaker: Roz
text: Really?  Do you feel okay?

speaker: Moira
text: Yes.  Now do me a favour and hand me those cigarettes.

speaker: Roz
text: You know, these things do come with a warning.

speaker: Moira
text: So do you, darling.  I let you in.

speaker: Frasier
text: _(to passing residents)_ Good afternoon.  How do you do?

speaker: Norman
text: _(o.s.)_ Is that Dr. Crane?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.

speaker: Norman
text: Dr. Frasier Crane?

speaker: Frasier
text: _(going into room)_ Yes.  Have we met?

speaker: Norman
text: No, but I thought that was you.  I recognised your voice from the radio.  I listen to your programme all the time. Norman Webster.

speaker: Frasier
text: _(shaking hands)_ Well ah, it's my pleasure.

speaker: Norman
text: Are you here visiting somebody?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh no.  I'm just here with a friend of mine, Roz.  She's here doing some community service.

speaker: Norman
text: Ah, the Angel of Death, nice girl.  Y'know, I remember one day I was listening to your programme, and ah, it was right after my wife died and I was going through kind of a rough patch.  You told this guy who was going through the same thing that he should keep pictures of his wife around to help with the transition.  That was a good idea.

speaker: Frasier
text: So you started keeping pictures of her?

speaker: Norman
text: That wouldn't make much sense now, would it?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, no.  Well, what did you do?

speaker: Norman
text: Well, I remembered when we were dating, Helen made this life mask of herself for art class, and I had my daughter dig through the attic, and lo and behold, _(picks up porcelain mask)_ she found it.  This is the way she looked when we met.  Isn't she beautiful?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh yes.

speaker: Norman
text: So you were right.  Every night, before I fall asleep, I run my fingers over Helen's beautiful face, and it takes me back to all those wonderful years we had together.  It made a world of difference. _(carefully places mask on table)_ I want to thank you.  You really helped me.

speaker: Frasier
text: You've no idea how nice it is to hear that.

speaker: Norman
text: Would you excuse me?  It's time for me to take one of my many pills.  Make yourself at home. _(goes into bathroom)_

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you.  _Frasier picks up the mask and admires it.  He then closes his eyes and runs his fingers over it. In the process, he manages to drop it. We hear it smashing._

speaker: Norman
text: _(from bathroom)_ What was that?

speaker: Frasier
text: Nothing!  Nothing, ahh, I just knocked your ashtray over.

speaker: Norman
text: _(re-entering room)_ I hope it wasn't damaged.  My grandson made that for me at summer camp.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh no, it's intact.  Not the tiniest chip.

speaker: Norman
text: Set it back on the table.  You know how attached you get to family things.  Do you have children, Dr Crane?

speaker: Frasier
text: _(on his knees, looking for the missing nose)_ Yes.

speaker: Norman
text: Dr Crane, are you on the floor?

speaker: Frasier
text: I was just ah, tying my shoelace.  Yes, yes I have a son. I'd much rather hear about your family. _(searches under bed)_

speaker: Norman
text: Well, I have four sons and one daughter.  You wouldn't happen to be single now by any chance, Dr Crane?

speaker: Frasier
text: _(resurfacing long enough to say)_ As a matter of fact, I am.

speaker: Norman
text: So's my daughter.  I'll tell you about her first.  She's a sweet thing.  Beautiful, too.  Just like her mother. _(Frasier finds the missing piece, gets up)_ Same cheekbones, same nose.

speaker: Frasier
text: _(looks at the nose in his hand)_ What a lovely nose it is.

speaker: Moira
text: So there are four of us in the raft, and I see we're heading into a patch of white water.  Suddenly, we slam into a rock, and the next thing I know my teeth are flying into the Colorado River.  I damn near dived in after them.  Those teeth cost more than the whole trip.

speaker: Roz
text: You've had quite a life.

speaker: Moira
text: I suppose.  Never got arrested, though.  Good for you.

speaker: Roz
text: It wasn't so great.  Y'know, it was the first time I ever got pulled over and couldn't flirt my way past it.

speaker: Moira
text: Oh, that's almost as bad as the first time somebody calls you "Ma'am."

speaker: Roz
text: That happened the other day.  It's been kind of a rough week.

speaker: Moira
text: I bet I know just what you're thinking: this is only the beginning.  It's only gonna get worse from here.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, yeah.

speaker: Moira
text: I'm eighty-one now.  And every morning, I open my eyes and I see the sun streaming through the window.  I hear the birds chirping, I smell the coffee brewing down the hall, and I walk into the bathroom and I look into the mirror.  And do you know what I say to myself?

speaker: Roz
text: _(almost mesmerised)_ What?

speaker: Moira
text: AARGHHH!

speaker: Roz
text: _(shocked)_ What the hell is that?!

speaker: Moira
text: That's the second thing I say!  The point is, it is only gonna get worse from where you are right now.  Well, what did you want me to say?  "Life gets better with every passing year?" You want to hear that, you go talk to Mrs. Adleman.  You can't miss her.  She's the one in the TV room with the inflatable seahorse around her waist.

speaker: Roz
text: Well you're not making me feel any better, Moira.

speaker: Moira
text: It's 'coz I can't.  Nobody likes to get older.  But it doesn't mean you can't enjoy yourself.  I'll tell you a funny story. Last Thursday, I hacked into the main computer here and changed the schedule.  So now, I get all my sponge-baths from Eduardo.

speaker: Roz
text: You're kidding me.

speaker: Moira
text: Look, you're way too young to be concerned about all this. Don't waste the best years of your life worrying about something you can't control.

speaker: Roz
text: I know.  I know you're right.  Y'know, I wouldn't care about getting older if I thought my mind was gonna be as sharp as yours is.

speaker: Moira
text: I'll tell you a funny story.  Last Thursday, I hacked into the main computer here and changed the schedule.  And now, I get all my sponge-baths from Eduardo.  _Cut to Norman's room.  Frasier is searching the room for some glue. The broken mask is lying on the bed._

speaker: Norman
text: With the exception of not being able to watch Willie Mays steal second, or Michael Jordan on a breakaway dunk, not a whole lot I feel I missed out on.

speaker: Frasier
text: _(looking through a chest of drawers, quietly)_ Uh-huh.  Ah, listen, you got any glue around here?

speaker: Norman
text: I don't think so.  Why?

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, the onyx has popped out of my cufflink and ahh, I was just hoping I might be able to re-affix it.

speaker: Norman
text: The closest thing I have is denture adhesive, it's on the dresser.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh good, good.  It's worth a try. _(starts putting adhesive on the mask)_

speaker: Norman
text: These pills may keep me alive, but they sure don't keep me awake.  You find it?_(goes over to bed)_

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.  Yes, you know I think this just might do the trick.

speaker: Norman
text: You know, the worst part about all this is that I used to be the kind of person that never got tired.

speaker: Frasier
text: _(trying to get Norman to stand)_ You know, perhaps we should take a brisk walk.  Get that old circulation going!

speaker: Norman
text: No, that's okay.  It's close to my bedtime anyway.

speaker: Frasier
text: Seems like you have a visitor, Norman.

speaker: Norman
text: _(without getting up)_ Come in... Come in... Probably Mrs. Adleman.  She was an Avon lady before she lost her mind.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, my goodness, that is a smashing robe.  You know, I'm in the market for one like it myself.  Why don't you stand up, maybe I can read the label.

speaker: Norman
text: _(bending over)_ Come over here and have a look.  I seem to be sitting on something. _(stands up)_

speaker: Frasier
text: Ooh!  My cufflink! _(grabs the nose and re-affixes it)_ All right, you know, I'll just ahh, place it back in here carefully and... a-ha.  Well, there we go.  Good as new.  Yes well ah, Norman, I can't tell you what a nice time it's been spending the day with you.

speaker: Norman
text: It was nice of you to drop by.

speaker: Frasier
text: _(going to the bedtable to put mask back)_ My pleasure.

speaker: Norman
text: Oh, you're over there?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh yeah, I was just having one last look at Helen.

speaker: Norman
text: Isn't she beautiful?  Such delicate features.

speaker: Frasier
text: _(with feeling)_ They certainly are.  Well Norman, it was a real pleasure.  I hope you keep listening to my show.

speaker: Norman
text: I sure will.  You're a good man.  Not a lot of people left with your kind of integrity.  _Frasier leaves.  Out in the corridor, his conscience bites. He re-enters._

speaker: Frasier
text: Norman, ah... I have a little confession to make.  I didn't... I didn't drop your ashtray, I dropped the mask.  The nose broke off.  I feel just terrible.

speaker: Norman
text: Well, that's why you needed my denture adhesive?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.

speaker: Norman
text: Usually, it works pretty well.  I must have dropped that mask ten times... I am blind, you know.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, certainly is a relief to hear that.  Well you know, I better get out of here before I do any further damage.  It was great meeting you. _(goes to leave)_ Would you like me to leave the light on or off?

speaker: Norman
text: Surprise me.
